dialog.text: Why does trying to change feel like I'm dragging a mountain?
dialog.instructions: young boy, breathy, urgent, vulnerable—curious question

dialog.text: Because you carry resistance like a backpack—stuffed with 'shoulds', old promises, and every time you swallowed a feeling.
I don't even know what's inside that backpack anymore.
That forgetting is the shadow's language. It collected what you couldn't look at so you could keep moving. Now it's heavy because you've stopped noticing it.
So do I just throw it away? Rip the straps off?
Pushing only makes you carry more. The work is simple and brave: stop running. Sit. Name one weight. Breathe into it. Listen to why it stayed.
Okay—there's shame. My father called me lazy when I failed. I still feel small when I try.
Say it plainly. Thank that part for trying to keep you safe. 'Thank you for keeping me small; you tried to protect me.' Then ask it what it needs to let go.
I said it... and a knot in my chest loosened, like a little air leak.
That's the start. Resistance is heavy because it clings to who you think you must be. When you welcome those parts, they stop posing as protection and become teachers.
So the inner work is not fighting the shadow—it's learning from it, again and again?
Yes. Small acts of presence—feeling, naming, thanking, releasing—shrink the load. The mountain stays; your backpack gets lighter. Your world changes because you stopped carrying what wasn't yours.
I want to keep unzipping it, one pocket at a time.
Begin now. Feel one weight, name it, thank it, and let it move. Then share one step you took today in the comments—your courage makes the next person feel less alone.
dialog.instructions: coaxing, inviting—call to action, compassionate close
